thread.title: Dreaming of a wet Christmas? | News | ojaivalleynews.com
thread.title_full: Dreaming of a wet Christmas? | News | ojaivalleynews.com

author: Perry Van Houten
title: Dreaming of a wet Christmas? | News | ojaivalleynews.com
text:
Southern California could get a good soaking from “a potentially significant storm” that’s due to arrive over the Christmas holiday, forecasters said.
Southern California could get a good soaking from “a potentially significant storm” that’s due to arrive over the Christmas holiday, forecasters said.
“For those of you who have been wishing for rain, you must be on Santa’s nice list this year,” said the National Weather Service in Oxnard.
The atmospheric river-type storm system was forecast to sag south over Ventura County on Tuesday, Dec. 23, with a 50% chance of rain and a quarter inch to a half inch of rainfall possible, the NWS predicted.
“Tuesday remains the day of transition,” forecasters said. “The forecast now calls for the bulk of the rain to fall Wednesday (Dec. 24) through Thursday morning (Dec. 25).”
Preliminary rainfall totals over the Christmas Eve/Christmas Day time period were subject to change, but early predictions indicated 2 to 4 inches for the coast and valleys, and 4 to 8 inches for the foothills and mountains.
“It is too early to get a handle on rainfall rate predictions,” the NWS stated on Thursday, Dec. 18.
In Ojai, high temperatures in the lower to mid-60s were forecast over Christmas, with overnight lows in the 40s.
Any rain would be the first since late November, a month that broke rainfall records across Southern California and brought Ojai’s seasonal rainfall total (since Oct. 1) to 9.55 inches, according to the Ventura County Public Works Agency-Watershed Protection.
As for chances of a white Christmas in the Southern California mountains, temperatures during next week’s stormy pattern “remain too warm for any significant snow,” the NWS stated. “Snow levels will be over 8,000 feet but will start to fall later Thursday (Dec. 25).”
This weekend, Ojaians will continue to see dry conditions and high temperatures in the 70s to around 80.
Then, a “seemingly endless and everlasting ridge” of high pressure will begin to break down, allowing a return to onshore flow and the redevelopment of marine layer clouds, the NWS said.
Forecast model agreement “falls off pretty rapidly after Thursday,” forecasters said, “but there is a potential for another system over the weekend of the 27th and 28th.”
For the latest forecasts and weather information, see weather.gov/lox/.
For current rainfall totals, go to vcwatershed.net/fws/reports/rain-season-report.
For emergency information in Ventura County, visit vcemergency.com.
Senior Reporter
